Title:
Glomus ibericum, Septoglomus mediterraneum and Funneliformis
pilosus, three new species of Arbuscular Mycorrhizal Fungi
Keywords:
arbuscular fungi, Mediterranean sand dunes, molecular
phylogeny, mycorrhizae, new species
Abstract:
Three new arbuscular mycorrhizal fungal species named
Glomus ibericum, Septoglomus mediterraneum and Funneliformis pilosus are
described and illustrated. In the field, the three species were
associated with roots of Ammophila arenaria, Elymus farctus, Otanthus
maritimus and Echinophora spinosa colonizing maritime dunes located
along the Mediterranean coast in the Eastern of Spain. The novelty of
these species is supported by morphological, molecular and phylogenetic
analyses. Single-species cultures of S. mediterraneum and F. pillosus
have been obtained using Trifolium repens as host plant, both forming
arbuscular mycorrhizae, whereas single-species cultures from G. ibericum
could not be obtained. Spores of G. ibericum usually occur in
sporocarps, rarely singly in soil or inside roots; S. mediterraneum only
forms single spores in soil; while F. pillosus occurs in sporocarps and
singly in soil or inside roots. The respective SSU-ITS1-5.8S-ITS2-LSU
nrDNA sequences placed the new species in the genus Glomus, Septoglomus
and Funneliformis, all of them separated from previously described
species.
